text: I hope you have enjoyed this rant almost as much as I have enjoyed putting off the stuff I really need to be working on rn

That's why these days when you see someone talk about neoliberalism they're almost certainly gonna be slinging some absolute trash analysis. but in those (inreasingly rare) instances when its the only concept that really works, it's frustrating that they've shat all over it

The crisis and fascist resurgence we're going through is neoliberalism running out of steam: it is not particularly useful for analyzing current shifts (except that you always need to know how we got here b4 you can know where we're going).

By failing to center that core racialized and racializing technology, borders, you get a nationalist analysis (neoliberalism = domestic austerity + cynical cultural liberalism), a redefining that dovetails perfectly with the anti-anti-racist class-first nonsense they also push

Once I stopped thinking of borders and nation-states as natural facts but as political weapons wielded to manage wages, prices, + production, then neo-liberalism becomes clear: a more conscious and politicized embrace of this fact.

I'm hardly gonna go to bat for longue duree theory entirely (as far as wingnut Marxist historical schools I prefer Tronti's "workers in resistance invent everything, the bourgeoisie simply recuperate the ideas") but history politics and capital are global and always have been

Also on the shit list: intellectual historians who romanticize the Mount Pellerin society as some kind of cabal of genius supervillains. I blame them for Adam Curtis being taken seriously, he precedes them but they saved great-man theory through a critical historical idealism

It is not a helpful lens for looking at say a rainbow painted cop car. Austerity in the global north is part of neoliberalism but only if you understand it as linked with a deepening authoritarianism and local state-driven debt based extractivism in the South

Anyway, neoliberalism is a helpful way to analyze how capitalism responded to the upheavels and crises of the long sixties, post-fascist and neocolonial reintegration of Europe, the third world and the former socialist blocs into a world where US was bread basket and policeman

Obsession with neoliberalism's relationship to the state as a way of misanalysing both capitalism and the state by imagining that labor reforms/the New Deal were like the height of political possibility, a fucking impressive decade and a half of confusing people

So much bad politics from imagining the US two party system as exemplary of politics as a whole. Like the most theyll say is "you know in Europe the Dems would be right wing" instead of like "the US model of executive republicanism is actually deeply anti-political and confusing"

They were helped in this by the liberal obsession w/ "neocon" pretending that neoliberalism represented one wing of the US capitalist class rather than a global response to anti-colonialism and the long 60s. "Neocon" was just a right wing rebrand like "compassionate conservative"

They did this through a straight decade of exhausting "boy aren't we tired of talking about neoliberalism" talking about neoliberalism and the discourse was just so fucking boring that people just wandered away from this actually helpful (if a bit vague) periodization

Pretty impressive how the Jacob*n crowd has sucessfully redefined "neoliberalism" to mean "refusing to do government programs and 'woke' capitalism" rather than "capital's response to the profitability crisis via debt, financialization and globalized infrastructure"
